TEXT: The applicant , GPE , has both GPE and GPE nationality . She was born in DATE and is living in GPE , the GPE . She is represented before the ORG by Ms Y.M. Schrevelius , a lawyer practising in GPE .
The facts of the case , as submitted by the parties , may be summarised as follows .
On DATE the applicant moved from LOC to the GPE where she married a GPE national , Mr ORG On the basis of that marriage she obtained a residence permit .
The applicant ’s daughter , PERSON , who had been born into the relationship between the applicant and CARDINAL Mr ORG in LOC on DATE , stayed behind in the care of her maternal grandparents .
On DATE a son , PERSON , was born to the applicant and CARDINAL Mr M.A.

It had been the applicant ’s intention to send for her daughter in DATE , which seemed to her an appropriate moment as she expected to have found a job and to have completed a professional training course by that time . However , her marriage breaking down in DATE thwarted these plans . As she was no longer residing with her husband , she applied for an independent residence permit which was granted in DATE .

The marriage was officially dissolved in DATE . The applicant acquired GPE nationality on DATE . She experienced difficulties obtaining proper accommodation , but this problem was solved in DATE . In DATE the applicant ’s father fell seriously ill in LOC due to which , the applicant submitted , the grandparents were no longer capable of taking care of S.

In DATE the applicant addressed a letter to ORG , stating that she wished for her daughter to grow up within her family , consisting of herself and her son PERSON , in the GPE and that she would be able to take care of her daughter ’s upbringing . She appended a declaration made by PERSON ’s father in which he consented to his daughter going to the GPE to live with the applicant . The case - file does not contain a reply to this letter .

On DATE the applicant filed an official request for a provisional residence visa ( machtiging tot voorlopig verblijf ) for her daughter with ORG of ORG . This request was rejected on DATE on the grounds that a stay of DATE was intended and that the application did not meet the relevant conditions laid down in GPE regulations . The applicant ’s objection ( bezwaar ) against this refusal was rejected on DATE . Her subsequent appeal to ORG of ORG ( Afdeling Bestuursrechtspraak van de Raad van State ) was rejected on DATE by the latter as unsubstantiated since the close family ties ( gezinsband ) between the applicant and her daughter were considered to have ceased to exist .
On DATE the applicant filed a new request for a provisional residence visa for S. This was rejected on DATE . The applicant did not apply any legal remedies against this decision

On DATE the applicant applied for a third time for a provisional residence visa , which was rejected on DATE . Again , the applicant did not have recourse to any legal remedies against this decision .
On DATE entered the GPE on a short stay visa ( visum voor kort verblijf ) , granted for the purpose of visiting relatives .

On DATE the applicant filed a request for a residence permit ( vergunning tot verblijf ) for S. On DATE the Deputy Minister of Justice ( Staatssecretaris van Justitie ) rejected this request , by concluding that the applicant relied on the same facts as those submitted in respect of her earlier requests for a provisional residence visa and that the reasons to reject those requests remained pertinent . The decision underlined that the applicant ’s daughter had entered the country on a short stay visa whereas the aim and the intended duration of her stay were not in compliance with the purposes of such a visa . The Deputy Minister held that this breached a rule of general interest .

Referring to the need for a restrictive immigration policy , the decision further stated that , unless international law obliged the GPE to grant admission , aliens could be allowed residence only if this served “ essential interests of the GPE ” ( wezenlijk Nederlands belang ) or in case of compelling reasons of a humanitarian nature ( klemmende PERSON aard ) . Neither of these conditions was met in the case of S.

On DATE the applicant filed an objection ( bezwaar ) through counsel with the Deputy Minister of ORG , underlining that her child could not have a normal existence in the LOC and that there were solid reasons why the applicant had been unable to bring her child to the GPE before DATE .

On DATE the Deputy Minister rejected the applicant ’s objection concluding that there were no grounds to justify a reversal of the initial decision since no new facts or other circumstances had been adduced and the grounds for rejection had been correct .

On behalf of S. the applicant lodged an appeal against the decision of the Deputy Minister with ORG of the Hague ORG sitting in GPE ( arrondissementsrechtbank te ‘ s - Gravenhage nevenzittingsplaats GPE , Enkelvoudige Kamer voor Vreemdelingenzaken ) . She requested an interim measure ( voorlopige voorziening ) to the effect that her daughter would not be expelled while the appeal was pending and invoked LAW in support of her claim .

As a rule , anyone wishing to apply for a residence permit in the GPE must first apply from his or her country of origin to the GPE Minister of ORG for a provisional residence visa . Only once such a visa has been issued abroad may a residence permit for the GPE be granted . An application for a provisional residence visa is evaluated on the basis of the same criteria as a residence permit .

In general , the Minister of ORG ( Minister PERSON ) decides on requests lodged by aliens for residence in the GPE ( LAW ( DATE ) ) . The Minister of ORG can refuse entry and residence on general interest grounds ( gronden aan het algemeen belang ontleend ) .

In view of the situation in the GPE as regards population size and employment , Government immigration policy DATE defined at the time in the DATE Aliens Circular ( Vreemdelingencirculaire DATE ) DATE is aimed at restricting the number of aliens admitted to the GPE . In general , an application for a residence permit in the GPE is granted only if the individual ’s presence serves an essential national interest or if there are compelling humanitarian grounds to do so ( LAW of the DATE Aliens Circular ) .

The policy for admission for family reunion purposes was laid down in LAW of the DATE Aliens Circular . It provided that the following persons , where relevant , may qualify for family reunion if certain conditions ( relating to matters such as public policy and means of subsistence ) are met :
– a person ’s spouse ,
– a minor child born into the marriage who actually belongs to the family unit ( gezin ) , and
– a minor child born outside the marriage who actually belongs to the family unit ( e.g. a child of CARDINAL of the spouses from a previous marriage or a foster child ) .

The phrase “ actually belonging to the family unit ” ( “ feitelijk behoren QUANTITY ” ) used in GPE law overlaps only partly with the term “ family life ” in LAW . The former is understood to mean , for instance , that the close family ties ( gezinsband ) between the child and its parents whom it wishes to join in the GPE already existed in another country and have been maintained . For the rest , the question of whether the close family ties should be deemed to have been severed is answered on the basis of the facts and circumstances of each specific case . Factors taken into consideration include the length of time during which parent and child have been separated and the reasons for the separation , the way in which the relationship between parent and child has been developed during the separation , the parent ’s involvement in the child ’s care and upbringing , custody arrangements , the amount and frequency of the parent ’s financial contributions to the child ’s care and upbringing , the parent ’s intention to send for the child from the GPE as soon as possible and his / her efforts to do so , and the length of time that the child has lived in a family other than with the parent . Living together in the GPE without a permanent residence permit is not seen as restoring severed family ties .
